div.p: THE PRINCELY PELLICAN.

ROYALL RESOLVES PRESENTED In sundry choice OBSERVATIONS, Extracted from His MAJESTIES Divine Meditations: WITH Satisfactory REASONS to the whole Kingdome, That His Sacred-Person was the onely Author of them.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: His Grounds inducing Him to this worke.

div.p: UPon the instancy of s • ndry Persons of accompt and quality, to whose ample favours I must ever acknowledge my selfe highly obliged; having such influence over me, at no amicable respects could more indeere me: I was induced to returne them some Satisfactory Reasons concerning diverse particulars mainly reflecting upon His Majesties Divine Essayes lately Published: and for a Living Memoriall of Princely piety, and devotion, to all Posterities recommended.

Now, their Reason of importuning my Pen to this Task, proceeded from their long knowledge of me for many yeares, to be a Constant Servant to His Sacred Person: and to whom (without arrogance be it spoken) His Majesty was oft-times pleased to communicate His private Councells and Addresses. Neither was the Service I did Him (so much out of an integrious and sincere Spirit, I dare avouch) at any time since these unhappy distractions, prejudiciall to the Peace of the Publique; or the unsetling of those High Affaires, which at first sight pretended safety to the State: and satisfaction to every loyall and well disposed Subject.

Neither, indeed, (to decline all prejudicate Censures touching His Majesties gracious disposition that way) would His Sacred Eare lend the least attention to any suggesting Instrument of Division: but with a pious aversion, or distaste to such fomenters, returne them a sharp reproofe; though their advice might seeme never so conducing to the vindication of His wrongs; or re-investing Him in His owne.

This I dare confidently attest for truth, as one who had remained constantly in my Attendance upon His Majesties Person, even to the last Man: when we were all expressely injoyned to be removed from our Gracious Master: whose love to His owne was so great, as this Injunction of our departure from Him, estranged us from our personall attendance; but never from the memory of His goodnesse: nor the individuall tie of our Cordiall allegeance. For I dare confidently assert, that this awfull Command was so grievous to some of us, as the Sentence of death had been with more cheerfulnesse received by us; then our removeall from His presence, whose gracious aspect operated so powerfully on all our motions.

Hence you receive the Reasons, whence I was pitch't upon this Taske; which I shall no lesse succinctly then sincerely returne to the honour of my Just Master: with clear satisfaction to all such, as stand doubtfull of the reality of so princely and imparallell'd an Author.

First then, To the Ground which induced His Grace to this work; He expresseth Himselfe in the very first Entrance, or Introduction to those His Divine Essayes: The Cause of His remove or recede from this Parliament: wherein He layes down the Motives of His Departure; with His integrious desires of all concurrency with that Great Councell of State; in whatsoever might hold consistence with the peacefull Governments of His Kingdomes; without the least intention of trenching upon the Liberty of His Subjects, or imposing any illegall burthens upon their shoulders. This I have heard Him oft-times second, with this patheticall expresse: O that My Subjects knew but the integrity of mine Heart towards them! But understanding upon what desperate hazards He run, and how all His Royall intendments for the Publique were mis-construed: Nay, that His owne Person could hardly be Secure without Securing; after sundry private Addresses (to divert more open and dispersing jealousies) He resolved, having found all His endeavours and proposals unsatisfactory, to withdraw Himselfe for a season from His Parliament; hoping by that meanes to make Them His, with His absence and sweet temper'd indulgence; which to His great greife, as He professed, He could not procure by His presence. But contrary
to His expectance, This revived that wound, which He hoped, might have been partly, if not perfectly cured; For this desertion of His Two Houses, by the aggravation of some Incendiaries, whom God forgive, cryed up His designes to be nothing lesse then aiming at a Tyrannicall Government: to make His People Slaves: and enrich His Exchequer by His Subjects ruine. And too many credulous Eares were ready to give attention to these unjust and injurious Aspersions; receiving for truth whatsoever the poyson of viperous tongues had maliciously suggested: and to bring an Odium upon His Sacred Person, publiqucly dispersed.

Was it not then high time to vindicate His traduced Honour by His Pen, which He could not with safety doe in Person? It was the Maxim of a serious Moralist; who had found by experience, that Innocence summoned before a Seat of Injustice, was a sufficient object for Sufferance: If it were sufficient to accuse, who could be innocent?
This was my Royall Masters condition: His breast could not be so transparant, as to eye His integrity: nor His Person without mis-prision, to plead His own Apology.

Many yeares Debates drawne out by the lines of our cunningst Projectors, had resolved what they meant to doe with Him: before they acted this fearfull and horrid Tragedy upon Him. They meant to make Him a Glorious King, and so they have made Him: but to unking Him first, to discover the Zeal and Allegeance they bore Him.

But to omit these, let us give a litttle more clear satisfaction to such, whose prejudicate eyes be not wholly unfilmed, touching His moderate composure and carriage after His recesse from His Parliament. Take a full survey of His Princely demeanour: and you will not finde any predominant passion, or intemperate spleane working on Him. Though many odious, scurrilous, and treacherous Libells were daily by an un authentick Priviledge poasted up, and published against Him: So oft as they came to His hand, He perused them with a modest smile, pittying their indiscreet boldnesse, for mis-spending their time on such scandalous Subjects.

But I intend to wipe off these (such were His words) with a spunge
of Truth. It shall be my Taske, at spare houres (and many such it seemes, My Parliament will admit M • ) to undeceive My People; and to rectifie their mis-guided judgements, who are not led away by the spirit of Errour.

These were the Grounds that • nduced Him to this Worke. The pursuit whereof, as it conduced highly to the content of His mind, and inward peace in the penning: So may it render no lesse satisfaction to any unprepossessed judgement in the reading.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: The Conference He had with some of His intimatest and apprehensivest Courtiers, touching some particular passages in that work.

div.p: HAving entred thus farre upon His purposed Taske: and in a private addresse for the Publick interest, ingenuously laid Himselfe open, how, and upon what Grounds He was moved to call the last Parliament; being a Councell so usefull (as He conceiv'd) for disposing and rectifying the Constitution of a distempered S • ate; as He was not more induced thereto by others advice, and necessity of His Affaires, then His own choice and inclination: as one, who alwayes thought the right way of Parliaments most safe for His Crowne, and best pleasing to His People. He was pleased some few dayes after He had retired from his Parliament to communicate his thoughts in his Garden at Theobalds, to some of his Gentlemen, who were nearest to Him; and of whose intimacy and abilities He stood most confident; how he had set his hand to Paper, to vindicate his innocency in the first place; by shewing the reasons he had of receding from his Parliament; which he hop'd could not chuse but render full Satisfaction to all his Subjects; unlesse they were of such a temper, as had pertinaciously asserted a dis-affection to his Person; and that not so much as one line had falne from his Pen, which with Honour he might not confirme, were it racked by never so rigid or uncharitable a construction.

His next Essay, as he told us, He intended should take its discourse from the faithfullest Servant and incomparablest Statesman that any Christian Prince could possibly rely on. One, said he, whom I cannot without a pious & religious sorrow remember: condemning my selfe in nothing more, then suffering my hand to thwart the resolution of my heart: having so expresly delivered my thoughts, and in so publick a manner; as beside my owne conscientious feares, which incessantly awaken me, the relation of so ungratefull an action cannot but to succeeding times redound highly to my dishonour.

To this a Gentleman of his Privy Chamber (and one now eminent in the Eye of the Publick) made answer; That this could not be for imputed an Errour of His, but to Their doctrinall Assurance, who maintained the conveniency of it; and made good his Subscription to it. O said he (and this he delivered with a deep sigh) but it is not safe for Princes to pin their faith • upon timing Prelates sleeves! Though their knowledge make them unexcusable of Errour; their future account shall neither lessen my Guilt, nor salve mine Honour.

Hereto presently replyed one (whose late arrest by death, has freed Him from incountring with sadder Fortunes) Sir, if the Sence of that Action have such strong influence o're your thoughts; that the dispersing thereof abroad may so much accrue to your dishonour, I should hold it an act of more Princely policy in you, rather to close then to lay open such a wound, as may wound your Fame.

q.p:
O no, in no case (N E D) said His Majesty. The way to cure wounds, is not to close but discover them. They rankle by being closed before they be cured. As for Princely policy, I hold none better then sincere piety. This it is will onely secure Him: and subject his outward affections to the Soveraignty of the inward Man. For my part, this shall be my constant Resolve (and it shall be my daily prayer, that no earthly Object may weaken it in me) that my Sinnes may be ever before me. For there is such a pretious Eye-salve in a pious teare, (being properly called the Wine of the Angells) as it allayes the distempers of an afflicted Spirit. And truly, Gentlemen, weigh but my present condition in this particular, and you cannot chuse but conclude, that this Balm •
of
Gilead may prove more truly cordiall, and Soveraigne for me, then the best Court-solace, or Civet-advice, were I in the cheerfullest and securest estate that any worldly Prince can enjoy. Our Scholists tell us (and our owne Synderisis attests no lesse) that to sinne against ones Conscience, even in mattters of indifferency, edifies to Hell. What may we then think of Actions partaking of an high and Criminall nature? The losse of a mans life (said that Absolute Commander) cannot be recompenced, nor made good by any benefit, or act of Grace that may be conferred upon his Survivour. Gentlemen, you may believe it, (for out of a deep and impressive remorce doe I speak it) that the disgusts of our Grand Senate, nor all the injurious affronts they can put upon me, may in reason so much perplex me, as the least thought of that inexcusable wrong I did to my faithfull Servant; whose high Ablilities, as they were more to be admired then parallel'd: So his industrious Service was in civill thankfulness to indear me more, then ever any Subject (if I may properly speak it) obliged his Soveraigne. For his safety, with whatsoever else was most dear unto him, he ingaged for my improvement. His want of health, at such time as he lay sick at my Lord of Leisters, witnessed how much his enfeebled body had suffered by rough and tempestuous Seas, and intemperate weather in his late Irish passage hither.

All which, with much cheerfulnesse, he not onely encountred but sleighted. Having arrived here, and left the Coast of Ireland, where he was both fear'd and lov'd: was he not afterwards questioned for his life, even upon those Commands, which my Commission injoyn'd him to act upon his Allegeance? And can I r • teine these lesse then with a thankfull sorrow, not onely to lose a Loyall-knowing Servant: but to gratifie him with an Injunctive Sentence of death for his faithfull Service? In the sad recollection of these, I may seriously protest, and with a clear conscience avouch it, that there is not so much as the least tincture or sprinkling of bloud besides this, that can be deservingly laid on my Soule; though the fury of my malitious Enemies causelesly labour to impeach me with one of an Higher Nature. But one day it will appear unto the world, that These, who thus guiltlesly accuse me, be the onely Incendiaries of a civill mischief;
imbroylers of the State: and such Seditious Innovatours, as their only designe, in their pursuite after private ends, will tend to the ruine of this Kingdome.

div.p: In this sort was His Majesty pleased at that time to communicate his griefes unto us: and with that passionate innocency, as it wrought strongly upon our attention.

After this, he tooke into his serious Consideration, all such doubts, as might object themselves to his second thoughts, in the divulging that Essay touching the Earle of Strafford: whether the world might not worthily tax him either of levity or pusillanimity in the survey of that Action. At likewise in his Declaration of the Moving Cause of his recede from the Parliament: whether such Reasons as He alledged, would bear weight in the Skale of equall judgements. Which, after due deliberation, He concluded would not onely appear satifactory to his People, but necessary in his own particular; forasmuch as those Corrupt Members that had begot a distemper in the whole Body, strove to lay an Odium upon his Person; for his desertion of the House without just cause.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: His resolution of proceeding with it; after his serious debate of those doubts.

div.p: WE know well that mens sufferings receive the liveliest impressions from the draught, or Representative of their Sufferers. It was the saying of a wise Greek, Any mans pe • b •• my owne, is a stranger to my paine. In which sense may that Morall Position in this place hold proper relation.

He who recommends those Annals or Memorials of his Actions, Sufferings or Indignities to a suceeding Remembrancer, when his own abilities may performe that Taske, and accomplish the work in his own Time; may be compared to an •• wise T • stator; who leaves large Legacies to be bestowed on such Persons after his death: but the Estate from whence those Legacies should arise, falls into the hand of a prodigall Disposer: who long before those flowers which were bestow'd on the Testators Corpse are withered, has quite forgot the tenure or purport of his Will. He findes whatsoever was bequeathed to others, little enough for his owne expence.
Such was the folly of this Testator, to depend upon the honesty of a profuse and carelesse Executor.

These Considerations (questionlesse) wrought infinitely upon His Majesty, He reteined a deep sense of those insupportable affronts and indignities he had suffered: and how even those Persons, on whom since the first beginning of his Raigne, he had amply conferred his Royall favours (though since paid home in their own coyne) exprest themselves most ungratefully bitter in the pursuite of their malicious designes. Albeit, so tender was he of their Honour, and so hopefull of the future recognition of their Allegeance; as his desire was rather to shadow them, then name them.

Howsoever, in this proposed Task, which at spare houres he intended to prosecute, according to the issue of his proceedings, whether good or bad, He continued his resolution: that Posterity might witnesse for him, whether his demeanure merited
any such dis-esteeme as the Assemblies of his two Houses had of Him.

Many times, and in some of our hearings, would he expostulate the Grounds of these distastes. How any of those Grandees, Some whereof he had undeservingly advanced to the Highest and most Commodious Places in his Courts of Judicature; should entertaine such jealousies touching his Person: and why they should proceed with such an over-powring Command, without so much as the least reflex, or loyall relation to his Prerogative Royall.

q.p: Must their plausive promises (said he) conclude in this; to estrange me from their Councels by their harsh & uncivill usage; to barre me from that Negative Vote which my Regall interest may justly exact of them; to brand me with an ignominious Note of intending to infringe their Priviledges: and in an hostile way of surprizing their Persons, whose endeavours (as they pretended) had no other aime then redresse of an abus • d State?

Is this the way they meant to goe, when they told me, They would make me the most Glorious Prince that ever raigned? Well; it shall be my Supreme Care to rely on his Sacred Providence; which I am confident will never faile Me: for, full of deceite is the heart of Man.

The groundlesse Jealousies of those of the Lower Rank; nor the setled Designes of the Higher, who have set their hearts to do mischief, shall never discourage Me from the Conscientious Execution of that Regall Office whereto HE hath called Me. He it is, in whom I trust; and he it is, under whose wings I shall be safe, should those Enemies of Peace, who persecute my Soul without a cause, never so subtilely, nor malitiously labour to intrap Me. For God is good unto Israel: and to all those who walk in sincerity of heart before him.

This then, shall be my resolve; with a strict and impartiall Scrutiny will I examine my heart: and in the Search of it, I will suffer no discomposed thought to raigne over it; but wholly dedicate it to him who gave it. By him Princes rule: may his Rule be my Guide through all My Raigne. He deserves not the Stile of a Prince, who amidst the greatest tryalls that humanity can encounter,
submits not himselfe to the Will of his Highest Soveraigne. Nothing can befall me, that may equall those indignities which HE suffered for me. May all I go about be undone, rather then his Will undone.

div.p: In this manner, no lesse fervently then frequently would His Majesty at set times usually deliver himselfe: and in His recollection of these, returne to His Study: where he addressed his happy pen to these pious Devotions.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: His reason of concluding every distinct Section, with a Meditation or devotionall Psalmody.

div.p:
IT hath beene observed by his Chaplaines in Ordinary; and by us too, who by our Places, were nearer Attendants to his Person; that though his desires were to be constantly vers'd in all parts of Sacred writ, yet he took such infinite comfort in the Psalmes of David, as he would usually upon occasion repeat Sundry Psalms by heart from beginning, to ending. And in Conclusion thereof, would call to mind that Observation of Saint Augustine touching that Book:Aug. sup. Psal. In every part of Scripture I finde usefully Something; but in the Book of Psalms I finde a Store-house of all things. A rich Store-house of all Spirituall Provision. Cordialls for the afflicted; Corasives for the impenitent; Salves for all Sores; Cures for all griefes; Balmes for all wounds; Solaces for all soules;Ibid. Medicines for all Maladies: Receipts for all Infirmities. Armed with this divine furniture, His Majesty amidst his Greatest Trialls (as never Prince grapled with more for number, nor more grievous for measure) could with a resolved patience talke with his Enemy in the Gate. Nay, amidst all those disgraces and indignities put upon him, he had learn'd in imitation of that Princely Propheticall Patient, to possesse his Soul in Patience: and to stop his mouth in the presence of the unrighteous. He frequently reflected upon Davids troubles: and in the Survey of them, upon Davids courage and constancy; how he stuck fast to Gods promise: and with much Spirituall comfort relied on
His providence. He had found by Experience, that the Lord, on whom he depended, was stronger in fighting for Him, then all such as fought against Him. He had been Young, and now was Old, yet did he never see the Righteous forsaken, nor their Seed begging their bread.

This our religious Josias duly observed: and in his Sufferings became thankfull. For (said he) if David, a Man after Gods own heart were thus afflicted: if his Enemies imagined such mischiefe against him: nay, if his familiar Friends, and Acquaintance who fed at his Table, made his Table a Snare to catch Him: What might his Soul expect in these Evill dayes, where impiety had so farre prevailed, as Schismes & Divisions had invaded and imbroyled the peace of the Church: Rebellion threatned a fearfull massacre to a flourishing State: where Loyalty was held Delinquency: Orthodoxall Divinity, doctrine of an Apocryphall quality: Sincere Devotion, heathenish Superstition: Ornaments of decency approved by Antiquity, to beauifie the Sanctuary; ragged reliques of pollution, prophanenesse and idolatry: What could he (I say) expect ought lesse then a ruin'd State, with an unsecur'd Guard to his owne Person? Complaints He heard daily: and his desires were to redresse them: but, alas, his desires were in the worst sense interpreted. Those, who, were principall Actors in these Combustions, suggested to his deluded People, that His Majesties pertinacy was the ground of their misery. How his desertion of the Councell of State, assembled for the safety and prosperity of the Publick: with his attention to Corrupt Councellours, would indanger the whole Kingdome. These, and such reports usually came to his Ear, and in their relation wounded his Princely compassionate heart. Meane time, his frequent addresses to his Parliament, (and in a character below himself; with such a wooing mildenesse and sweet humility was he indued) witnessed the desire he had that the House might reteine that opinion of him, as his intentions towards them justly merited. And that such a right sense and understanding might be got amongst them, as all groundlesse jealousies might be removed: and that Great Worke for which they were assembled, seasonably promoted and accomplished. But when his assiduate addresses might produce no fruit; He held Devotion the onely Refuge and Anchor-hold
to calme the storme of a troubled Spirit. Which, is he many times professed, wrought so heavily upon him, as for diverse nights, Sleep was a stranger to his Eyes. But such was Gods goodnesse ever to him, as his afflicted Soul was never so much d • press • d, but by repairing to those Rivers of Divine Comfort, the Psalmes of David, he became infinitely refreshed: So as, the burthen of his griefs was nothing so heavy, as the Solace which that Book afforded him, was delightfully stored with all Spiritual Melody.

This it was which induced His Majesty to end every Meditation with a Psalme: that as the former lay open to the world his distressed Condition: so by acknowledgement of Gods mercy, and resignation of his will to his all-sufficient Mercy, he might returne Comfort to his thirsty Soul in the Conclusion.

The repetition, or renuall of our Griefes, though they may in some measure allay the bitternesse of them by a seasonable discovery, and temperate delivery: yet they necessarily require some precious Balme, or soveraigne Receipt to cure them. Now, what cure more requisite then spiritually to converse with One, who had drunk of the same Cup; and partak't deeply of the like affliction, whereof he himselfe was become a Sharer?

This was His Majesties condition; Davids parallel for affliction, in every particular saving onely an Absalon. Indeed a Rebell sprung from ones own Bowels, is such a Bowel-sorrow, as it exceedes all others.
This onely excepted; our late gracious Soveraigne was in nothing inferiour (in the Skale of affliction) to that Princely Sufferer.

And Subjects may be p • operly said to h • ve relation to the • r Soveraig • e, as Children to their Parents: which a • mi •
ed, it cannot be denyed but His Majest • had many Rebells a rising from his owne bowells.No wonder if the wounded Hart flie to Dittany, having such vertue to cure Him. Seeing Psalmes minister such variety of Spirituall Solace, no marvell if our Afflicted King used them.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: The Comfort He conceived in it, and received from it.

div.p: THe wearied Labourer, who has borne the heat of the day, cannot entertaine rest with a more cheerfull welcome; The Sea-beat Mariner, after he has incountred with Surging Waves, and impetuous Windes, cannot with more pleasure strike into his calme and secure Harbour, then an afflicted Soule in communicating her perplexed thoughts to a discreet compassionate Friend; who is both willing and able to afford her such counsell as may redound to her comfort.

It was the saying of a sage and serious Moralist, If a Friend should performe the Office of an affectionate visitant, in presenting himselfe to his necessitated Friend, and not relieve him; Sick, and apply nothing to him; disconsolate, and not comfort him: Such an one might be rather said to mock him, then accommodate him; scorne him, then supply him.

It is handsomely observed by One in his addresse to His Majesty; That he had in his Three Kingdomes, three sorts of People: The first, confident and faithfull; The second, diffident and fearfull; The third, indifferent and doubtfull. Which he marshalls in order, and distinguisheth them in this manner.
The first were with Him in their Persons, Purses, (or desires) and good wishes.
The second were with Him neither in their Purses, nor good wishes, nor (with their desires) in their Persons.
The third were with Him in their good wishes, but neither in their Persons, nor Purses, nor Desires.

His Majesty shared in the first and last, in his introduction to these sable and sullen times: but in the close of his mis-fortunes; when the Cup of his Affliction became more fully imbittered: He partak't onely in the Seco • d.

Their dis-allegeance had dryed up the Streame of their bounty; estranged their good wishes: and dis-ingaged their Persons from any Service that might be consistent to the assistance of His Majesty:
or present the least expressive Argument of their Loyalty.

Now in this deluge of his sorrowes, when he was deprived of all outward Supplies; was it not needfull for him to have in store some inward Comforts, to refresh his troubled Spirit? And these he found plentiously, and preciously treasured in these Divine Ejaculations: which, as he many times confessed, breathed to his languishing Soule most hope, when least of hope appeared. He found how the Lord had other wayes, then onely by the Sword or Speare, to relieve him. He, who had power to make a ready passage through the Red Sea for his People; at such time, when the Enemy was hehind them; and the Mountaines inclosed them: and all visible hopes of refuge were estranged from them: Even that God of Hosts (such was his confidence in the Almighties providence) would deliver him from the Hand of the wicked Doer: and in his due time (for he knew well Mans extremity to be Gods opportunity) make those bones which he had broken to rejoyce. His trust was on the Rock of his Salvation: neither did he fear what Man could doe unto Him, so long as the wings of the Holy One overshadowed Him. Nay, should he kill me (said he) yet will I trust in him. It is he that made me, his appointment that Anoynted me: and whose blessed protection hath hitherto delivered me. I know he has mercy in store for him that walkes innocently before him; It shall then be my Principall care to have a circumspect eye over my wayes; that I offend not with my tongue. And with a resigned will rather to forgoe my Crowne, then to forg •
his favour, or become his dishonour who bestowed it on me: and which, if it seeme pleasing in his sight (whose eyes are upon all the wayes of men) he will continue to Me and my Posterity against all the insults or assaults of a spitefull Enemy.

As for me, I will from the very bottome of my heart, acknowledge, that it was good for me that the Lord has humbled me, lest I should be exalted above measure; and so perish in my Folly. I have seene it, (and I apply'd it to my selfe, and found comfort in the application) how many Children play'd wags in the street, and how one amongst all the rest was catcht hold of, and corrected; the rest untoucht: and I gathered hence, that it was the Naturall Father of that Child, who took upon him to correct him: and how his affection to him, caused this Correction of
him. This was my Heavenly Fathers course, with me: and I have kissed the Rod, and he has taken pitty of me.

q.p: My resolve then shall be, rather to desire a dissolution, then to injoy the pleasures of Sinne for a season. The wages of sinne is Death: by his assistance then that gave me a Being; I will play the painfull Labourer in my Calling, that I may receive my wages from my Faithfull Master in the Evening; My day-work small, but my reward great.

Were I the most miserable divested Prince, that the whole world could present on this active Theatre of earth; that State-catastrophe should not so much perplex me, as one thought of a prepensed rebellion against him that made me. No better Resolve for a King, (as I have elsewhere exprest) then to preferre his Conscience before his Kingdome. Such an one may be truly held more then a Conqueror: having such a continuall feast within him, as nothing without him may distemper him: and of such an absolute composure, as he's fortifide in suffering in any thing, saving his honour.

I know well, and you, Gentlemen, who attend me, will witnesse so much with me, that the indignities, and personall aspersions throwne upon me, had exceeded the bounds of humane suffering; had I not been enabled by his goodnesse, and through him strengthned with such Christian patience, as their unprevailing intendments to provoke me, inraged their passions more then they could work upon mine; in being dis-appointed of that which they most desired, my anguish. For in all their fruitlesse Assayes, I remembred how David accounted it his duty to keepe his mouth close whilest the wicked were before him.

As also in the vindication of my owne wrongs, I held it not onely the most pious but prudentest Christian Stratagem, to subdue the fury of an implacable Enemy, rather with a pleasing neglectfull Smile; or as my condition rather challenged, a Princely sleighting, then any impatient opposition: as persons below my esteeme, and consequently unworthy my hate: Besides, I considered, how Revenge was often more sinfull then the Offence. Why then should I awaken my Soul to doe that, which might disturb the quiet of my Soul?

All this while, I was not ignorant how these Plotters of Mischiefe did not onely thrust, but thirst sore after my life, to take it. And with what plausive Principles they laboured to withdraw the hearts and affections of my Subjects:Principles in use for dis-alle • ging Subjec • s. The trust of Kingdomes is put upon them; which, so long as they faithfully discharge, they are to be honoured and obeyed; but once being violated, their Covenants are broken; and they are no longer Kings; The safety of the People, is the Supreme Law: and People were not made for the good of Kings, but Kings for the good of the people.

div.p: These were working Notions for stirring Spirits, and stuffe enough for any Hammer to strike and mould out some Masterpiece or other upon the Anvile of Sedition.

p.q: Whereas, thou O Lord, knowest all my wayes, for my works are ever before thee: Thou knowest I wished no greater advantages by this War, then to bring my Enemies to moderation, and my Friends to peace. Thou, I say, knowest right well, that I alwayes held the Safety of my People essentially consistent with mine owne: and though thou madest me Soveraigne over this Land, yet I never took upon me to Soveraignize over the Law. The addresse of their wrongs was my care: else I had not with such freedome and cheerefulnesse assented to a call of this present Parliament.

div.p: Having discoursed in this sort with much efficacy and pious Devotion: He acquainted us what imparable comfort he received from that brief Manuall, which he had in part composed, and meant to continue it; not onely amidst those brackish and distempered seasons, to allay his discomforts: but to communicate it likewise to such, who were jealous of his Safety, and tender of his Innocency.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: What choice houres He reserved for this Exercise.

div.p: IT is written of Holy Lewis the French King; that He usually bestowed certaine houres of every day upon distinct taskes; lest by doing nothing, His frailty might bring Him to doe what was worse then nothing.

The Morning He dedicated to devotion, Reading and Contemplation; the Meridian for his repast and nourishment: the Afternoone for administration of Justice: with some spare houres at convenient Seasons for moderate recreation; being such as might refresh Him, but not too freely seize upon Him. In all which imployments, it was his especiall care (as is observed of Him) that his Hand, as a ready Almoner to his Heart, might be ever active in exhibiting Offices of Charity to all such as were in necessity.
This was a rare Princely President; being such a patterne of piety, as might be more admired then imitated.

The like example is recommended to us of a devout Father, in those primitive dayes of the Church: whose custome it was to injoyne Himselfe an hourely Taske for private Devotion, Meditation, Speculation: with certaine actuall or Manuall imployments for reliefe of Himselfe and others.
No houre of the day was lost, which He might either Spiritually or Corporally improve: So serious He was in the due expence of his time; lest his stock of Grace should decrease.

This it was moved Holy Hierom to take a mightly account of Himselfe; as every carefull Houshoulder should doe of the Government of his Family: O my soule, what hast thou done to day? Nay, to present to his thoughts, by a deep apprehension of the sound of the Last Trump • , that fearfull Summons: Arise ye dead, and come unto Judgement.
But you will say, this familiar converse with Death and Judgment, is better knowne to a Cell then a Court.

For the Habitation betwixt Heaven and a C • ll (as one
saith) holds such contiguity, as their locall distance cannot divide them from a spirituall Society.

For the Prayers of the Saints (whensoever such Saints are immured in those Cells) pierce the Heavens, and communicate a Divine Blessing for that Peace-offering. But to finde this Soule-solacing Devotion; and Spirituall Conversation raigne in Princes Pallaces; where we may commo •
ly see a World of Men, but a Wildernesse of good Men; where Sinne for the most part gallants it in his footcloath: and where vanity with more then Military boldnesse keepes to usuall Rendesvouze; this were a rare Sight, and an Object deserving Admiration.

That Athenian Professour observing a Person descended from a Princely Family to enter his Schoole, and in Arguments of Dispute, to expresse himselfe with much facility and elegancy, both a Philosoph • r, and in Politicks a State-Councellour; returned thi • relation to his Friend, as some rare and miraculous Occurrent: We have lately found in our Schooles (said he) an Object of stupendious wonder, a Prince, a Philosopher, and a Lawyer.

Yet all this might we truly, and without assentation instance in our late Gracious Soveraigne: For at such houres as He reserved for Phylosophicall discourse, His Houshold Chaplaines will witnesse thus much for Him, that His promptnesse and pregnancy in all Arguments, approv'd Him both a • acute and solid Proficient: and for His Judgement in Law, what without Ostentation He spake of Himselfe at the Barre, befor • that unpresidentall President, may by sundry judicious and learned Professours of the Law, be confirmed of Him; That He knew our Lawes as well as most of our Gentlemen in the Kingdome. For on these as other Morall Studies, it was his usuall custome to bestow some select houres: and to improve His Reading by conference and reasoning: which so highly inabled Him (being richly indued with quicknesse of Capacity, and a retentive Memory) as no Argument, were it never so spiny, tending to Divine or Morall discourse, could evade Him. And these Disputes▪ He pursued with such a becomming modesty: as no Opposition could beget in Him the least of passion.
Although in passages of Recreation and Pleasure, He might appear otherwise.

Minutius records of Mercurius Trismegi
• stus, that even the Heathen, because he was a great Philosopher, would not use his name without great reverence: What honour then is due to Philosophy, when it goes cloathed with Majesty?It was a strange vote, to wish all Kings Philosophers, or all Philosophers Kings: and yet in Him might we finde these lively presented. A brave contexture of State; where Crownes are no lesse dignified by personall worth, then imperiall stile. This makes Princes truly memorable to Posterity; when their known abilities seasoned with humility, even in their death, be it naturall or violent, perpetuate their memory.
It is true, what was sometimes spoken of two Roman Emperours, of different times, and di •• erent tempers.

The Learning of Augustus made his Courtiers Scholler • : whereas the Ignorance of Licinius made his Followers Loyterers. So representative and reflecting too were the personall examples of Princes actions to their following Shadowes. Albeit, no Rule so generall but admits some exception▪ E • perience may informe us, that Princes may be professours, and able proficients in Philosophy; and yet their Reteiners meere Pretenders; Glowormes of the time, and Pencioners to Vanity. These value time at no higher rate then as a light Companion; whom they entertaine more for sport then profit: whereas such precious graines at fall from times Cruet, are not to be so lightly scattered.

Now amidst these houres so usefully disposed, as none could be better bestowed to the improvement of any Person that presented Majesty: HE told us, that as his Morning Devotions took up the first; So He ever reserved the next for those Meditations which He had now in hand. For He conceived that no houres were more happy either to the Conceipt or Memory then those prime rayes of the Morning: For, said He, My condition is not so cleare from intrusive cares, nor invasive feares; which all the day long are encountring Me, as to recollect my selfe at all houres. Thoughts devoted and dedicated to God; as they should be our Darlings, so are they to be digested when the minde is most at quiet. For as it is impossible to fix ones bodily eye both on Heaven and Earth at one time: So is it for the eye of our inward affection to reflect upon heavenly Affaires, and at that instant to be intangled with worldly
cares or temporary feares. Albeit, I thank God, since my first bickring with these disloyall Affronts, which the braving insolence of uncivilized Subjects, and those on whom I have in the plenteousest measure showred My bounty, and immerited favour, have darted on me; I resolved with my selfe to intertaine these transitory Crosses with transitive cares; being sent to try Me, not to foile Me: to beleagure, not surprize. For I beheld them farre below Me; therefore unfit to subdue Me.

And, as for those who persecuted Me without a cause; I accounted no otherwise of them then divine Epictetus did of his two mortall Enemies, Anytus and Mellitus; they might kill Me, but they could not hurt Me. They might seize upon My Person; but My soul they could not touch.

Thus have you heard what Choice houres He reserved for this Exercise of Devotion. Prime thoughts were dedicated to prime houres: with the first appearance of the Morning-Sun, He prepared His affection • for this Spirituall businesse: addressing it with a single and sincere heart to that rising sun of Righteousnesse, blessed for ever.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: How this work, so farre as He had continued it, came to be taken at Naseby; with other Papers, and private Letters of high concerne in His Cabinet: and how recovered.

div.p:
IN the Field at Naseby, where the battell was so variously carryed, as to the judgement of the approvedst Disciplinaries, and Field-officers that were in the Action of that day, the Victory rather inclined for a long time to the Conquer'd Party, then those who appeared afterwards Masters of the Field. Nay, where an Ancient experienc'd Commander, and a man of Honour;Gen: Ashley. One, who had been bred up a Souldier, being at that time highly imployed in the Princes Service, and in the next action at Sto, amongst others taken Prisoner; protested, that from his first knowledge in Armes, he never knew a Battell close with such a strange event, contrary to all expectance: Neither to this hour •
(said He) can I finde out the reason how His Majesty should lose the day. For so confident was I of the utter Defeat, and Rout of the Enemy; as no visible designe that ever I was put upon, could promise me more assurance. So as I should heartily wish that His Majesty might be perswaded to desist from His further pursuite of Martiall Affaires, and to compose these sad d • stractions of His Kingdome by other mediating wayes: For I plainly see that the Hand of the Lord is not with us: And afterwards directing his Speech to the Conquering Party: Nay, Gentlemen, the work is done: unlesse a Division among your selves discompose it.

There, I say, at Naseby, upon discomfiture of His Majesties Forces, amongst other rich prizes was this inestimable Gemme, the continuation of His Divine Meditations, which He had gone along with to the Successe of that day, seized upon by the Enemy, with other Papers and Characters of Concerne, being inclosed in a Cabinet; reserved for that purpose.

But such was the benignity of the Conquerour, or Divine providence rather, that would not suffer so excellent a worke to perish in Oblivion: nor to be exposed to the rude razing hand
of an illiterate Souldier;A rare Civility from the hand of a profest Enemy. that it was recovered above all expectance, and return'd to His Majesties Hand: though the perusall of His Papers were left to a more racking censure.
Which infinitely cheer'd Him amidst those insuccessive events that accompanied His Forces: using these or the like words upon the regaining of them.

I see the gracious Eye of Heaven will not suffer Me to be deprived of all comfort: though my owne subdue me; Posterity shall see by these Papers, that I knew how to subdue my owne passion: and solace my selfe with Divine comforts in the highth of My affliction: Though My Enemy gaine the Field; a composed patience shall crowne me with a braver Victory, then their successe had obtained of me: I know no triumph more absolute then a Selfe-conquest: and this it has pleased God in all our sinister Occurrents, to enrich Me with against all Assailants. May I cease to be, when I cease to be His, who wrought this influence on me.
Thus did His Princely Pen and mind close in a sweet Sympathy.

It is true, what one well observed touching His judgement of Bookes, That they were the best Councellours; the best Companions. Councellours to advise us in all our conditions; whether they were breathed upon by more prosperous or adverse gales. This it was that taught constant Camillus, neither to be transported with honour: nor dejected by a dishonourable Censure. Neither to be deluded by a light favourite: nor over-awed by an imperious Command.

Having strength enough to vanquish His Foe by smiling at indignities: and with a patient supporting of what His power could not revenge, purchase a seeming conquest of His Conquerour. Neither be good and usefull Bookes (for on such onely we reflect) meerly Councellours to instruct and prepare the affection to reteine an equall temper or composure in every condition: but they know likewise how to act the Office of good Companions, in Arguments and Helpes of Discourse; in a fruitfull expence of precious houres; by improving the conceipt; inriching the memory: and inabling every faculty to enter Lists upon any Subject of Discourse. For Bookes should not onely be deceivers, but improvers of Time. Account we are to give how we bestow our houres: Light and frivolous labours
are to be held uselesse, nay worthlesse expenders of the shortest minutes.

As in the choise of our Acquaintance, so in our approvement of Bookes; Such we are to receive into our bosome, as by our familiar intertainment of them, and conference with them, we may become bettred; but in no particular depraved or corrupted by them. This it was which moved that Learned, Sir F. B. but unfortunate States-man, to distinguish Bookes by these three Notions: Some were to be swallowed, some eaten, others chawed. Impertinent Discourses, such as afforded no benefit, but brought with them a danger to the Reader; Such were to be swallowed, or perfunctorily perused; not so much as relished, lest the appetite might be infected. Others there were to be eaten, in respect of their benefit; but neither in such manner nor measure, as if those onely were the breasts of nourishment. Whereas the last were to be chawed; or seriously ruminated; being such as ministred comfort to the spirit seasonably; suffered no inordinate affection to domineere over the will imperiously: but tended wholly to the accomplishment of the Reader, effectually.

All which in this Singular work of Meditation, and pious Devotion any dis-interessed judgement shall easily finde. For of THIS may be properly spoken, what was said (but in another sense) of Euripides Tragedies: So many Verses, so many sentences. A serious sinnewy-dialect without affectation: A cleare method in the discovery of His Princely affection: with an excellent contexture of every distinct Section to his owne comfort, and others satisfaction.

But as it is no strange thing for religious Workes to meet with the rigidst Censures: So a Person of high Command in this imperious Army was pleased to bestow this Censure upon this exquisite Piece at His very first sight of it: Saying, It was an handsome Piece of Hypocrisie. Whereas it may appear to the whole world, that His Princely Pen hated nothing more then to play the subtile Sophister with His Soule.

How greatly then are we indeared to the benefit of so unexpected a recovery? To have such a precious Jewell retrived; such an inestimable treasure preserved from the clutches of an imperious

〈1 page duplicate〉
Enemy; as reserve from the Spoile? which redounded highly to the deserving honour, and succeeding memory of His Majesty. For by this meanes, such as were causelesly jealous of His abilities, became satisfied upon the Survey of this incomparable Piece.

Though some there were (so deeply laid was the tincture of their malice towards His Person) as they desired nothing more then to eclipse His splendour, by dispersing reports abroad, that this worke was none of His penning: but one of His Houshold Chaplaines; Who by his studious endeavour not onely perfected, but withall possible speed procured it to be published, to beget an esteeme of learning and piety in His Master: as likewise to allay the rigour of approaching Sentence at Westminster: and by this work of his Devotion, to wooe His Enemies to commiserate His condition.
This, as those Pillow-prophets hop'd, upon Survey of His abilities, might mould them to compassion.
But their devise came too late: for this pretended issue of His braine, fell to be His Posthumus; so as, it produced no such effect as was expected.

This has been lately with a confident boldnesse reported by some (and those eminent Professours for the Publick) but how frivolous and malicious their Arguments appear, and with what facility evinced (being onely grounded upon an inveterate hate to His Majesties Person) shall be clearly, and demonstratively proved in the next Chapter of this our ensuing Discourse.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Satisfactory 〈◊〉 to rectifie their judgement, and evince their e ••• ur, who entitle these His Majesties pious Princely Devotions, to any other Authour.

div.p: SOme there be, (and those of the principall'st Favourites of our Grandees) who usually spread reports, that His Majesty was no such Authour of this Worke. Onely He might be acquainted with the zealous affection of some pious Chaplaine: who took upon him that task, meerly to dignifie the labour, and bring it into request, by sending it abroad under His Princes Name.

To delude the world too, They say that one Doctor Harris was the Composer of it. Others assigne it to Doctor Hammond. But these frivolous Commentings (for with a more proper stile I cannot cloath them) may be easily answered and evinced: proceeding rather from height and heat of Spleene; whereby they strive, as much as in them lay, to impaire the abilities of His Majesty: (who never all his time sent forth his lustre with that fulnesse, as his setting upon Earth hath shown it) then any ground of truth, as to any unprepossessed judgement may appear hereafter.
First, for Doctor Harris, it is well knowne, he had no relation to Him: He might pretend it, but never had it.

Neither to the houre of the Publishing of it (which upon the first Impression, by the singular care of the Printer, was exactly performed) had this supposed Authour (I am confident) so much as the least view of these Meditations. For during the time that we were permitted to attend His Person: and since such time as He first addressed his pious paines to this work; He had never any usuall society with us: nor accesse to HIM, who justly had command over us.

And for Doctor Hammond, those who read his works, will freely confesse, that no Idiom nor Dialect could be more different; nor to a discerning judgement more discrepant then these of His Majesties Meditations, and Doctor Hammonds Tractates or Sermons.

Rectè judicatur hic Mundus in nobis, si opûs perfidorum hominum non inveniatur in nobis. Ambros.His Majesty (as may appear by His whole Labour) desired nothing more then to be understood by His People: to remove all prejudicate Opinions: and to satisfie the whole world, that whatsoever He had done, held consistency with his Prerogative Royall; without so much as the least intendment of incroaching upon His Subjects Liberties: or assuming to Himselfe more power then His Progenitors legally claim'd.
In these He communicated His Pen freely, without any figurative elegancy; which He oft-times said, was a meer trifling of Occasions: or mis-spending of precious Minutes.

His condition was not to play with Paper: nor to pres •• t His Devotions to the Aire. He rightly knew in what state He stood; To Court the Parliament, He scorn'd it; and with a tinzell zeal to court the Almighty, He abhorred it.

His desire was to be the same. He did outwardly s •••• . Vulgar errour could not make Him lesse then He was; nor Pretenders to State-improvement impeach his true Zeal to the State. He never held Him the best Pen-man; who with least affectation communicated his own sense.

Shall I really (without which notion, nothing is here to your judgements recommended) acquaint you, with what he was pleased, and in his Table-discourse pleasingly disposed to impart to some of us? That the misery of a calamitous State had advantag'd him as much in some particulars, as it had lost Him. For, said He, the pretended losse of a State, has gain'd me a tongue. Passion, which usually made my tongue inarticulate, is become a stranger to Me. My long and assiduate course of suffering, has taken me from an opinion of Suffering. And in this I am happy, through a cheerfull imbracing of mine unhappinesse. Neither, said He, is this all the benefit that My present infelicity has brought Me; for this groundlesse distaste of the Publick has made me My own private Secretary.
I am now become my owne Amanuensis.

My Abilities, though meane, may now appear; for I have none to inable them. I have sometimes held it sufficient to dictate to a Pen; but now those Directories, by all likelyhood, are to be estranged from me. I must accommodate my Garbe to my present Fortunes: and conclude with this impreze: That Princes, in distresse, may not be asham'd to be their own Secretaries.
By these you may easily gather, that a • His owne apprehension was most sensible of his owne injuries: So his owne Pen represented it selfe the liveli •• discoverer of his Maste •• indignities.

One told Apelles, who was to make Him the draught of a ruin'd City; with a reflex to his owne Family; when that incomparable Artist had presented to Him the Minde or Idea of that Draught: That He might necessarily (if He intended to perfect the Draught) present Himselfe to the full Body; otherwise He failed in the display of those calamit • s both of the City and His owne Family.

Small doubt is to be made, but that the sufferer has ever the readiest pencil •
for pourtraying his owne Sufferings.

There is no ear, at this time especially, when all Kingdomes have with a sad admiration heard of this Princes Tragedy; and all Christian States stand amazed at his unpresidentall Tryall, and horrid. Treason acted upon his Person with all inhumanity: that have not received Notions 100 of this Princes worth: for pregnancy of wi • ; solidity of judgement: with a clear disposition estranged from vice, and invested with goodnesse: and in all (His flexibility onely excused, a knowne frailty to easie natures) gracefully accomplished.
The memory whereof, (not to insist longer on them) cannot but leave a deep impression in his sorrowfull Subjects, for the losse of so absolute a Soveraigne.
His Book, as it is here incomparably valued, so by this time in most Countryes dispersed, and in translating in severall tongues.

We may c •• slesly doubt of His Idiom: but I am confident,After times (when truth may be presented without a Vizard) will finde eminent Thuano's, to record this in living Annals to Posterity. that no Forraigne State (much more our owne) who by Legation onely have been known to his abilities, but will condemne their judgements, either of perversnesse or we • knesse; who hold Him not a contemptible Authour to such a Pious and Religious Labour.
Restraint to an unr • strained Spirit begot a brave Emphaticall Passion in his Pen, On that it had wrought like impression by way of Compassion, in his Subjects hearts to his Regall Person!

As for those late Additions annexed to his Divine Meditations; They might with more discretion have been silenced, the • published: being onely familiar Expresses of Fatherly affectio • to his Children: and those so digested, as if he meant not they should be divulged.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: His divination of the miseries that should befall this Kingdome by these distractions.

div.p: WHat true presages, as if by Divine revelation imparted, His Sacred Majesty foretold touching the approaching Miseries of this distracted State; as they were to have relation to the whole Kingdome in generall, the City and Army; I shall here in the conclusion of this Tract, truly and briefly returne you.

For the first, he devined, that as popular mixt State might seemingly at the first aspect please the people; who were satisfied with nothing more then Parity, by equalling those who before Lorded it over them: So they would find themselves much disappointed of what they expected, and whereon they rested: when those, who pretended for the Publick, should appeare meere advancers of their owne private ends; by labouring rather to impose new burthens on them, then to ease them: and by their Arbitrary power, in the end to inslave them.

They should finde, that their owne Favouri •• s should beare the sway; and that their servile condition should have good cause to bemoane their change of Government: Fishing in troubled waters suted better with stirring spirits, then persons of a plebei •• condition. Taking off Assesses, Levies and Free-Quarterings, might appeare plausive Aimes; but there was a Pad in the Straw, pressures and impositions of that nature, might more easily lose their name, then their weight.
This their depressed shoulders should in short time feele, though their hopes of an infranchised estate hall'd them asleepe, and secur'd them from danger.

Innovation to itching eares and Souldiers of Fortune, whose
onely harvest was in times of division, might bring glad tidings, but Traffick and honest Manufactory should find what it was to have no King. Which by meanes of no irregular liberty would in time erect such a State, as would produce Narceries for Thieves by Land, and Pyrats by Sea. Merchants and their Facctors should be sure to suffer: For what Forreigne •• ate would trust them abroad, who had either plaid the Traitors or acq • iesced to Treason at h • me▪
Innovation seldome beg • ts a Reformation, 〈…〉 ho • e a Monarchy was to be shap'd into an Anarchicall Pa •••• which He was pleased to illustrate by this witty and s • ritely ins •• nce.

One earnestly desiring Lycurgus to establish a popular State in Lacedemon, that the basest ••• ht have as gr • at authority 〈◊〉 the highest; was thu • answered by him, B • gindo d •• s • first in thine owne house; which he refused, and thereby ••• t the •• ju • tice of his owne demand.

Now to descend (said He) to our Hierarchie 〈◊〉 Church-Government; I am verily perswaded, that Spirituall
〈◊〉 whose only husbandry it is to sow i • food in the Lords Field needs as little agencie for dispatch of his businesse, 〈◊〉 ever he did since he was a falne Angel.

div.head: ALBIONS NIOBE: PRESENTING HER TRIBUTARY TEARES TO the Eyes of an abused Soveraignty. Huc veniant lachrymae, Ni • be quibus obrata mater?

lg.l: WHat will these Independents doe with thee
Deare Prince?This Elegie was composed that very morning (being the 30 of January, 1648.) when his Sacred Majesty took his last farewell at S. James's. where will they plant their Soveraigntie?
Two Sunnes can never shine within one sphere,

No more can T •••
and Nol one Scepter reare.
Must this Anarchicall hotchpotch in a State,
This indigested Pile mure up our Gate,
And suffer nought to entertaine our eares
But Arms, Alarms, and innovating feares?
Shall these Ac • phalists, who here in stead
Of Prince, set up a State without an Head,
Mount on their Barbe •• Barbs without controule,
And make a Groome o'th' Stable of Saint Paul?
Must their Recruiting City, whose rich Burse
This poore distressed Isle has cause to curse,
Feed these Echyd • a's in her faithlesse breast,
Who meane to hatch strange projects in her Nest:
And to her honour, or succeeding shame,
Quarter those Cayes that meane to plunder them?
State-starved AL • ION, what is thy intent?
To raise thy ruines from a Par ••• ment
Dissolv'd to Atoms! Pray thee look about;
See, Darby-house has sent her Consuls out
T'improve their wits; or regular their Note
From Presbyterian to the Armies Vote.
Brave Independents! who by slight of hand
Can foole those Cubbs, who eight yeers fool'd this Land!
Yet be compassionate; 'tis Valour's praise
T'imbelish cloudy dayes with cheerfull rayes.
Draco was taxed, though his Lawes were good,
By Demades, for writing them in blood.
You have two hundred Senatours to try,
Who know no more their Crimes then you or I.
And these must all to th'Barre: where meere pretence
Of being Foes, may leave them in suspence.
Which were extreame; that these who have so long
Weakned our State, to make our Forces strong,
Should for their ioynt surprizall of a King,
In your defence, march Heav'n-ward in a string.
But take your course! No censure's high enough
Upon a Cormorant, or Cornish Chough.
State-Sharke, Saint Rook, Pye, Popingay, or Kite,
A Senat Sycophant, Time-Parasite.
Vermin that make a spoile o'th' Warr'ners game,
Must find a nooze, and They'r to feele the same.
Nor has your boundlesse fury been lesse heady,

For you have dragg'd them intoWhere they had time enough their falls to mone, And shake their eares together, saving O • e.
Hell already;
When your Parol, like Pluto's lineall heires,
Gave Fynes first liberty to mount Back Stayres
With other faulty Members, whose disease
Has purchas'd from your hands a Writ of Ease:
Each may goe home, and play the Country Bore,
But never act a Senat-pagent more.
These have their H • gs to a faire Market brought,
Who by their Counsells their owne ruine wrought.
But now for method sake, that I may know
Where you intend your Agents to bestow;
Tell me, brave boyes of valour, where you meane
For Independencie to lay your Sceane:
Where your Designe takes ayme; whether for City,
Our gracious Synod, or our Grand Committee?
All must goe under lash; not one scape free,
Which drains no teares from ALBIONS NIOBE:
For there's no Man of Sense that seeth not
What mortall wounds by these our State has got.
—So! We observe your March, and in it see
Old Shiptons Wife makes good her Prophesie.
Downe with that braving Babel, whose high Pile
Shot stones to shake th'foundation of our Isle:
And with her golden Gravell par'd a way
For Horse and Foot to work her owne decay.
—See how that feverish Recruiter goes,
As if Corns took possession of his toes,
And numm'd their sense!— Nor dare he for his life
Mount with desire to his expecting wife,
Lest he beget more Beggers; for his Nest
Must be expos'd unto his Red coat Guest.
This He discovers plainly; that his Heire
Must reape no profit by his fruitlesse care,
Nor his profuser Oathes, nor artfull Lyes,
To set a glosse on his Commodities.
He must untrusse; and by his awfull foe,
As he came nak'd, so must he naked goe:
For though the Cities monthly exhibition
Mount to vast summes; this must be no Physitian
To cure the Cities Ulcer; their delay
Of succouring them at Colchester must pay
The Army their Arreares; which swell so great,
They must be squeez'd; 'tis folly to intreat:
For well you know, 'tis easie to betray
The Bleating Flock, when th'Dogs are ta'n away.
But leaving this sick State, we come to you
Who know no Cesar, nor what's Cesars due.
Alas! what has HE done? Admit his crimes
Held diapasan with these vicious times,
Must Feet pronounce a sentence on their Head,
This had been brave in you; & such 〈◊〉 thing As had been gratefull to your Highest King.And reare imposthum'd members in his stead?
It had in you an act of Honour been
To give him time his errors to redeeme,
And not to lop a Royall Plant so soone,
Before he fully knew what he had done.
A skilfull Gard'ner will not cut a limme
So long as there is hope. Deale so with him.
He'll prune, trim, dresse, and doe whats'ere is fit,
In hope with culture to recover it.
But your poore. Prince must by your Juncto dye,
Rest of his Right, and yet you know not why.
Afford us but one president like these
Through all those Syracusan tyrannies,
And we'll subscribe, your hands are cleere from blood,
Though they were cruell, and your Sov'raigne good.
Admit sinister Stars lowr'd long upon him,
Has he not borne himselfe as did become him,
So much admir'd for Patience in restraint?
A captiv'd Prince becomes a glorious Saint.
For He in suffering has more valour shewne,
Then you with all your Victories have done:
And thereby gain'd more love and loyalty,
Then if he had enjoy'd his liberty.
HERE eye those injuries that you have done him,
And in these Lines we tender look upon him.
Was't not enough to part him from his Wife,
But you must sue divorcement for his life?
Was't not enough to make him Prisoner,
But blast his Fame with vote of Murderer?
Which with such faire pretences gilded were,
As they'd beene diaphonically cleare.
"But those men onely merit high esteeme,
"Who seeme the same they be, be what they seeme.
Meane while be prayes for his perfidious foe,
"Forgive them, Lord, they know not what they doe.
He sighs, seeks, sues, these Civil Wars may cease,
And close these factions with a glorious peace.
Read all his Propositions, how they tend
In their Conclusions to no other end.
Read too his Meditations now in Print,
What zeal and what devotion there is in't.
—But ALBION's lost, quite lost!Illi • est Tr • a, ubi fum •• altè sc • pit in Coelum. Sen. in Tro. whose ruinous fall
Cryes out upon power Democraticall:
Mixing these words with her unpittyed grones,
"Lo! Lo! There's TROY-NOVANT an heape of stones!
—But I have done; Some Bard supply my place;
Deepe-furrowing teares have rivelled my face.
Nor must those teares be wasted, for they shall
Resolve to Amber at his Funerall.
STate shaking Cethegus, curst Catiline,
Dissect this horrid Treason of our time,
And tax proud Rome for holding yours a Crime.
Un-king a King, because He was too good!
Doome Him a Tyrant, who for Justice stood!
Cruell, whose hand was never dipt in blood!
Adjudg'd for living well, unfit to live!
Deni'd for heav'ns provision a reprive!
Traytor, for pleading his Prerogative!
Barr'd from Reply, when He at Bar was tryde!
By Achans and Achitophels defyde!
Kept from His Childrens sight untill He dyde!
Informe our knowledge, Heav'ns; there's some amisse
Skrean'd from our Skaly Eyes occasion'd this;
"To snatch three Crowns from him ('tis fear'd) frō His.
What might this be! —Me thinkes I see a brave
Creature of His awaking from his Grave,
Shewing that Hand which His Dismission gave.
Yet to Excuse that Error, there is writ
The Doctrine of our Prelats under it:
"It was an Act convenient and fit.
Ay me! How Cheerfull dayes produce sad nights
When Kings give care to Pulpit-Parasites!
Which Sceane is here presented in our sights.
A Prince decreed to forfeit his Command
By signing Others Errors with His Hand:
Creating so a Democratick Land.

Heav'ns judgement's Which might be imply'd by those words He spake before his Execution: God forbid that I should be so ill a Christian, as not to say that Gods Judgements are just upon Me; Many times he does pay Justice by an unjust S •• te • ce, &c. just▪ Let Soveraigns take heed
In Acts against their Conscience to proceed:
Ti ••• ists will finde no Advocates to plead.Timists will prove weak Reeds in time of need.
But those pure-crimson streamlings which were shed
On th'Sable Stage, where He resign'd His Head,
Seal'd with a deepe remorce, have witnessed
His peace is made; and that His Diadem
Cannot be now pull'd off by hands of Men;
"His Court's remov'd to New Hierusalem.
BEhold the Mirror of a Prince Pourtraid!
The living Embleam of a glorious shade,
Whose Chair of State was late a Scaffold made.
One, then whom never any did professe
More Zeal to th' Publique, and received lesse;
Of more desert, and brought to more distresse.
That reall lustre to our Royall Garter;
That late inlarger of our Cities Charter;
Whose Crown the Crime that made this Monarch-Martyr
Adieu Dear Prince; Death, like a loving friend
Hath Crown'd thy sufferings with a pe ••• full end,
While headlesse we our ruine most attend.
Nor can we lesse expect, Judgement's at hand
To scourge the follies of a sinfull Lo • d:
"What Brightman wrote we would not understand.
"From th' fatall period of a Charlemaine,
"Waine should a Kingdom in her Charles-waine▪
"But Prayers nor tears might call him back again.
"Lords should resigne their Paten • s to the Sword,
"Lurdane should equall any English Lord.

lg.l: GReat Duke, ar't gone! See what it is to be
A fruitlesse Plotter of disloyaltie;
An Agent for self-ends; A peace-pretender;
A State-betrayer for a State-defender;
A subtile Sinon, who had learn'd to shroud
His Crown-aspiring Projects in a Cloud,
White-liver'd Machavel, who marched in
By way of Progresse, not a way to win;
A cunning C • y-duch nurtur'd to betray
His fowle to th' n •• ze, and then to flie away.
But now the Old-one's catch, his Sentence past,
No more of Plots, Deaths-Sc • ffold acts the last.
By doing much He has himselfe undone:
"Englands contempt and shame to Calidon.
—Stay; let's invert His fate: and style him blest,
Exempt from grief, of peacefull day 〈◊〉 possest:
Admit him onely weary of His Sin;
As all the world was long since of Him.
For we may safe conclude Him fortunate,
Gaining like love above, as here of hate.

div.head: Upon the Earle of HOL • AND.

lg.l: SOme perfum'd Tapers h • ! Conduct this Lord
To the best Bed our lower Roomes afford.
A due to vanity! too much was spent
Of precious time in aiery Complement.
What is't with toyes to deck these Protean forms
When they must take their Lodging up with worms?
When these must be our Consorts in our Bed,
And feed upon us, who were in us bred?
—Some will demand, who's He lies here inshrin'd?
What was his Meane? How were his rhoughts inclin'd:

And th' Sylvan Satyr •
tells you in a word,
"A Silken-Civet-Comfit-Curtain-Lord:
A meere Platonick Love-pretender too,
Whose formall Cringes had the art to wooe
And win affection.—but these were toyes;

That Starry Galleri •
presents more joyes
And Courtly Solace to him in an houre,
Then he enjoy'd in two Kings Raigns before.
For if His thoughts fixt here so much on love;
They were transcendent, sure, in that above:
And of all Loves that are on Earth profest,
That which He dy'd for, Loyall Love, is best.
—M • rientes Aula reliquit
Exposit • s miseris t • rtoribus —
MUch honour usher this Heroick Herse,
While Muses, joyne in Counsell for a Verse
To crown the sacred mem'ry of his Name,
That preci • us Odour of a fragrant fame.
A glorious gallant Soul, who bravely dyes
To make his life a Royall Sacrifice
To re-invest his Prince: No prize too dear
To seat his Soveraign in his proper Spheare:
And though His vallour second not his wish,
Impute it Englands sin, no fault of His.
—Now eye that Scaffold! with what manly grace
He walks, He talks, and meets Death face to face!
A rare familiar garbe, where a pure brest
Makes Death no Bugbear, but a welcome Guest.
How He exhorn the Soldiery to bring
Unto His Throne their late-proclaimed King.
That heav'ns would to this Realme His peace restore;
This did He wish till He might breathe no more.
—Farewel brave Lord, thou needst no sumptuous shrine;
Thy worth survives the period of time.
But if thou must, let amber-trickling eyes
Rear one with this Impreze-Here CAPEL lies.
This shall suffice; for the world cannot have
More State then Stile of CAPEL on a Grave.
"Sweet Madam wipe your eyes; the Siedge is rais'd.
"Your Husband freed; God in his freedome prais'd.
